description.narrative: Conservation and sustainable management of key globally important ecosystems for multiple benefits Country:Kazakhstan

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: 1.A significant contribution made to the establishment of new forest PAs covering over 1.8 million hectares and to the strengthening of the management of new and existing forest PAs. 2.A number of innovative approaches, models, and techniques introduced, including the introduction of HCVF management practices, forest inventory and management planning that incorporates remote sensing data, the use of information technology for effective pasture management, public-private partnerships, economic valuation of ecological resources, and sustainable forest management incorporating climate change. 3. Multiple measures are undertaken to improve coordination amongst stakeholders with respect to biodiversity monitoring and wildlife law enforcement, and improve data management and knowledge dissemination.

comment.narrative: 1. There is not currently sufficient technical or financial capacity available to support the necessary process for expanding the protected area system of Kazakhstan to be appropriately representative of Kazakhstan’s forest ecosystems. 2.The current institutional framework of forest management units managed by regional governments is inefficient, and does not allow necessary strengthening of capacity for forest management. 3.There is currently poor coordination amongst national stakeholders responsible for biological monitoring, and wildlife law enforcement. In addition, data and information on biodiversity monitoring is not aggregated, or analyzed in a comprehensive way.

1. Comprehensive biodiversity monitoring programs were developed for the Katon-Karagai and Tarbagatai national parks, Markakol and West Altai reserves, which enable systematic work on monitoring key plant and animal species, taking into account the ecosystem approach. Atlases of key types of mountain forests of Altai, Northern and Western Tien Shan were prepared and published. 2. Scientific rationales were developed to expand the territory of the Zhongar-Alatau National Park, SNNP “Kolsai Kolderi”, Karatau Nature Reserve and create the Merke Regional Park. 3. In 3 regions of the country, a series of training workshops on the topic “Gender and Sustainable Management of Ecosystems” was held, within the framework of which an extensive information campaign was carried out on the creation of Public Councils in protected areas regarding the equal participation of both men and women in decision-making processes. Participants of the training sessions were employees of pilot national parks and reserves, forestries, NGOs of the East Kazakhstan and Almaty regions. 159 people were trained, of which 65 men (40%), 94 women (60%). 4. Work is underway to evaluate the national forest management system according to the international target scenario assessment methodology (TSA). TSA involves the preparation of 2 scenarios for the development of forestry for the long term. 5. A methodological guide was developed for monitoring forest fires on the basis of the ERS data to enable forestry and PA staff to conduct remote monitoring of forest fires, determine the coordinates of fire sources, and obtain relevant data to make decisions on fire extinguishing methods and assess the access to transport infrastructure, as well as carry out systematic monitoring of the state of forests in large areas. 6. The approaches and the scope of work in landscape planning and development of Functional Zoning Schemes were determined using the example of 7 pilot districts of the Almaty region. In order to develop approaches to sustainable pasture management, the current pasture state and management were assessed at 10 pilot sites in 3 regions of the country (Almaty, Turkestan, and East Kazakhstan). Priority pilot activities were developed to improve and reduce the degradation of pasture lands. 7. Analysis of the current situation and the existing practice of planning and conducting tourist activities in 5 pilot protected areas (Sairam-Ugam SNNP, Katon-Karagai SNNP, Charyn SNNP, SNNP “Kolsai Kolderi”, Syrdarya-Turkestan SRNP) was carried out. A unified format of the Master Plan for Ecotourism Planning in the protected areas was developed. The norms of permissible recreational loads on tourist routes in pilot protected areas were determined. 8. In order to increase the effectiveness of the fight against poaching and conduct quality monitoring of biodiversity, a SMART patrol system with the CyberTracker mobile application was introduced on the basis of the Sairam-Ugam National Park, enabling to keep track of performance indicators of the inspection staff and the wildlife monitoring. 9. To conduct large-scale comprehensive work on the study of the Kazakhstan population of the snow leopard, a 2-year contract was signed to determine the habitat and assess the state of its population. The first field studies were conducted in its natural habitats and corridors in the territory of the East Kazakhstan and Almaty regions. 10. 294 SEELOCK camera traps were purchased and installed to improve the snow leopard population monitoring system in the territory of 13 pilot protected areas and the Merke forest protection institutions.

1. Creation of framework for improving representation of globally important forest ecosystems of Western Tien Shan 2. Improvement of high -conservation value forest management system and effectiveness of pilot PA activities. 3. Implementation of fire prevention and protection measures for 8 target forestry units of Almaty and East Kazakhstan regions. 4. Provision of assistance with sectorial program development and forest conservation and sustainable use action plan of the Republic of Kazakhstan. 5. Identification of key steps for integrated land resources management based on landscape approach for 6 administrative districts of Almaty region 6.Preparation of the national annual report on results achieved in Snow Leopard conservation 7. Initiate activities for assessing Snow leopard population’s condition and food potential with the purpose to develop recommendations for National Snow Leopard Conservation Plan

1. In order to create a basis for increasing the representativeness of globally significant forest ecosystems of the Western Tien Shan, meetings were held with the participation of all stakeholders, representatives of the authorized body and akimat of the Zhambyl region 2. In order to assist pilot PAs in developing and updating Management Plans, a workshop was held on August 26-27, 2018 on developing a Management Plan for pilot PAs for 2019–2023. 3. The project analyzed and identified the needs for technical equipment of pilot PAs and state forestry institutions in accordance with the norms and standards for the conservation, protection and regeneration of forests and forest breeding for the full implementation of forest conservation, forest protection and reforestation works. According to the results of this analysis, 418 pcs of radio sets were purchased for 12 pilot PAs and 8 state forestry institutions. 4. The project provided expert support to the Forestry and Wildlife Committee of the Ministry of Agriculture in the preparation of the Investment Program for the development of forestry and wildlife until 2020. As part of this work, strategic directions for improving the legislative framework, proposals were developed on changing the regulatory system and monitoring, on the sustainable development of forestry, wildlife and protected areas. A Roadmap was prepared on the development of the forest sector, protected areas, hunting sector and fisheries until 2028. 5. Based on the initial discussions within the framework of the retreat in October of the present year in Almaty with the participation of representatives of district land services of pilot districts of the Almaty region, the baseline situation and problematic issues of land use planning were identified, joint activities were planned to introduce landscape approaches in sustainable land management 6. In order to obtain information on the results of the work on the snow leopard, with the participation of representatives of scientific organizations, environmental NGOs, representatives of governmental organizations, extended regional retreats were held in three project territories. 7. A regional meeting was held on collecting data in the field of the animal world conservation and monitoring. Information was collected from stakeholders to prepare a National Strategy and Action Plan for the conservation of the snow leopard.
